event_title: Operation Copy - Copy item to another Exchange mailbox folder
description: Copies a mailbox item to another folder within the mailbox. Moving/copying items can be routine organization or a tactic to stage messages for later exfiltration or to evade monitoring. Concentration into atypical folders or sudden spikes merit review. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Validate the action aligns with user activity and no data exfiltration is occurring. 1. Verify the destination and purpose of the move/copy activity. 2. Assess if items were staged in atypical locations or concentrated suddenly. 3. If suspicious, reverse the staging and prevent further rearrangement. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1114 - Email Collection

event_title: Operation Create - Create item in Exchange mailbox
description: Creates a new mailbox item (message, calendar item, etc.). Object creation often accompanies onboarding or architecture updates. Threat actors may create rules or objects to reroute traffic or maintain access. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: No immediate action if expected; correlate with user activity if suspicious. 1. Verify the business justification for the new object and its lifecycle owner. 2. Ensure properties do not introduce unintended exposure or routing behavior. 3. If created without need, remove it and confirm no dependent components remain. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1114 - Email Collection

event_title: Operation FolderBind - Access Exchange mailbox folder
description: Accesses (binds to) a mailbox folder to read or manage its contents. Read/bind actions precede collection or staging of information. Large volumes across folders or access to sensitive mailboxes may indicate reconnaissance or data gathering. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Spot-check for unusual access patterns (e.g., admin accessing VIP mailbox). 1. Check whether the volume and scope of access are typical for this actor and mailbox. 2. Look for rapid traversal across folders or high-interest content. 3. If abnormal, limit access scope and require confirmation of business need. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1114 - Email Collection

event_title: Operation HardDelete - Delete Exchange mailbox item permanently from Recoverable Items folder
description: Permanently deletes a mailbox item from the Recoverable Items (hard delete). Deletion events can be part of cleanup or retention workflows, but adversaries also remove items to hide traces. Look for clustering with prior access or move actions and whether deletions bypass recovery windows. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Confirm the deletion was authorized and reversible per retention policy. Review who performed the action and when. 1. Determine whether the deletion was intentional and aligned with retention or housekeeping. 2. Assess whether critical items are recoverable and if deletion followed unusual viewing or moving actions. 3. If malicious intent is likely, prevent further removals and restore essential items where feasible. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

event_title: Operation SendAs - Send message using Send As Exchange mailbox permissions
description: Sends a message using Send As rights on another mailbox. This reflects impersonation-capable activity where mail is sent from another mailbox's identity. It is often normal for shared mailboxes or assistants but can indicate compromise or misuse of delegation. Pay attention to the actor, target mailbox, and message characteristics to assess intent. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Verify delegated rights are approved; review sender, target mailbox, and message details. 1. Confirm that the sender is permitted to operate on behalf of the mailbox owner. 2. Review recent communication patterns for signs of impersonation or sensitive content exposure. 3. If misuse is suspected, remove the delegation and ensure only intended parties retain access. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.

Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Validate change control, maintenance window, and impact. Review configuration diffs and monitor post-change health. 1. Verify the destination and purpose of the move/copy activity. 2. Assess if items were staged in atypical locations or concentrated suddenly. 3. If suspicious, reverse the staging and prevent further rearrangement. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.

Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Validate change control, maintenance window, and impact. Review configuration diffs and monitor post-change health. 1. Verify the destination and purpose of the move/copy activity. 2. Assess if items were staged in atypical locations or concentrated suddenly. 3. If suspicious, reverse the staging and prevent further rearrangement. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.

event_title: An attempt was made to access an object
description: An attempt was made to access an object. Read/bind actions precede collection or staging of information. Large volumes across folders or access to sensitive mailboxes may indicate reconnaissance or data gathering. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Validate object access attempts. Check if sensitive files/keys were targeted and ensure access is expected. 1. Check whether the volume and scope of access are typical for this actor and mailbox. 2. Look for rapid traversal across folders or high-interest content. 3. If abnormal, limit access scope and require confirmation of business need. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

event_title: An attempt was made to create a hard link
description: An attempt was made to create a hard link. Object creation often accompanies onboarding or architecture updates. Threat actors may create rules or objects to reroute traffic or maintain access. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Review actor and context to determine if this event is expected or malicious. 1. Verify the business justification for the new object and its lifecycle owner. 2. Ensure properties do not introduce unintended exposure or routing behavior. 3. If created without need, remove it and confirm no dependent components remain. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Review the policy change for authorization. Confirm change control and impact on security posture. 1. Establish intent and necessity for the action. 2. Validate that it conforms to standing policies. 3. If not, reverse where safe and document the outcome. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

event_title: System security access was granted to an account
description: System security access was granted to an account. Read/bind actions precede collection or staging of information. Large volumes across folders or access to sensitive mailboxes may indicate reconnaissance or data gathering. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Ensure account changes were authorized. Review who performed the action and associated change tickets. 1. Check whether the volume and scope of access are typical for this actor and mailbox. 2. Look for rapid traversal across folders or high-interest content. 3. If abnormal, limit access scope and require confirmation of business need. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

description: A user account was created. Object creation often accompanies onboarding or architecture updates. Threat actors may create rules or objects to reroute traffic or maintain access. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Ensure account changes were authorized. Review who performed the action and associated change tickets. 1. event_title: A member was removed from a security-enabled global group
description: Indicates changes to group membership such as adding or removing members. Moving/copying items can be routine organization or a tactic to stage messages for later exfiltration or to evade monitoring. Concentration into atypical folders or sudden spikes merit review. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Ensure account changes were authorized. Review who performed the action and associated change tickets. 1. Verify the destination and purpose of the move/copy activity. 2. Assess if items were staged in atypical locations or concentrated suddenly. 3. If suspicious, reverse the staging and prevent further rearrangement. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Ensure account changes were authorized. Review who performed the action and associated change tickets. 1. Establish intent and necessity for the action. 2. Validate that it conforms to standing policies. 3. If not, reverse where safe and document the outcome. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools

Large volumes across folders or access to sensitive mailboxes may indicate reconnaissance or data gathering. Legitimate occurrences include planned administration or routine user activity. Suspicious patterns include unexpected actors, unusual timing, or bursts of similar events.
response_guidance: Validate object access attempts. Check if sensitive files/keys were targeted and ensure access is expected. 1. Check whether the volume and scope of access are typical for this actor and mailbox. 2. Look for rapid traversal across folders or high-interest content. 3. If abnormal, limit access scope and require confirmation of business need. 4. Identify the actor and target and verify the action aligns with current responsibilities or approvals. 5. Compare with nearby activity to determine whether this action is part of a normal sequence or an anomaly. 6. If unexpected, contain by halting further related changes and preventing repeated actions. 7. Revert unauthorized changes where safe and document the rationale. 8. Notify appropriate stakeholders if impact to confidentiality, integrity, or availability is suspected. 9. Record findings and outcome for future tuning and awareness.
mitre_technique: T1562.001 - Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
